questions.text: Explain the concept of object-oriented programming and its main principles
questions.expected_answer: Object-oriented programming (OOP) is a programming paradigm based on the concept of objects, which contain data (attributes) and code (methods). The main principles are: 1) Encapsulation - bundling data and methods together, 2) Inheritance - creating new classes based on existing ones, 3) Polymorphism - objects of different types responding to the same interface, and 4) Abstraction - hiding complex implementation details.
follow_up_questions: Can you give an example of inheritance in your preferred programming language?
What are the benefits of encapsulation in software design?

questions.text: What is the difference between a stack and a queue data structure?
questions.expected_answer: A stack is a Last-In-First-Out (LIFO) data structure where elements are added and removed from the same end (top). A queue is a First-In-First-Out (FIFO) data structure where elements are added at one end (rear) and removed from the other end (front). Stacks are used for function calls, undo operations, and expression evaluation. Queues are used for task scheduling, breadth-first search, and handling requests.
follow_up_questions: Can you describe a real-world scenario where you would use a stack?
What are some common operations performed on queues?

questions.text: Explain what Big O notation is and why it's important in algorithm analysis
questions.expected_answer: Big O notation is a mathematical notation used to describe the upper bound of an algorithm's time or space complexity as the input size grows. It helps us understand how an algorithm's performance scales with larger inputs. For example, O(1) is constant time, O(n) is linear time, O(n²) is quadratic time. It's important because it allows us to compare algorithms objectively, predict performance at scale, and make informed decisions about which algorithm to use for different scenarios.
follow_up_questions: What's the difference between O(log n) and O(n log n) complexity?
Can you give an example of an O(n²) algorithm?

questions.text: What is a database index and how does it improve query performance?
questions.expected_answer: A database index is a data structure that improves the speed of data retrieval operations on a database table. It works like a book's index, creating a separate structure that points to the location of data in the actual table. Indexes speed up SELECT queries by allowing the database to quickly locate rows without scanning the entire table. However, they also consume additional storage space and can slow down INSERT, UPDATE, and DELETE operations because the index must be maintained.
follow_up_questions: What are the trade-offs of having too many indexes on a table?
When would you choose a clustered vs non-clustered index?

questions.text: Describe the concept of recursion and provide a simple example
questions.expected_answer: Recursion is a programming technique where a function calls itself to solve a problem by breaking it down into smaller, similar subproblems. A recursive function must have a base case (stopping condition) and a recursive case (where the function calls itself). A classic example is calculating factorial: factorial(n) = n * factorial(n-1), with base case factorial(0) = 1. Recursion is useful for problems with repetitive substructure like tree traversal, mathematical sequences, and divide-and-conquer algorithms.
follow_up_questions: What happens if a recursive function doesn't have a proper base case?
Can you think of a problem where recursion might not be the best approach?

questions.text: What is the difference between HTTP and HTTPS?
questions.expected_answer: HTTP (HyperText Transfer Protocol) is the foundation of data communication on the web, but it transmits data in plain text, making it vulnerable to interception. HTTPS (HTTP Secure) is HTTP with an added layer of security using SSL/TLS encryption. HTTPS encrypts data between the client and server, ensuring confidentiality, integrity, and authentication. Modern browsers mark HTTP sites as 'not secure' and HTTPS is now standard for all websites, especially those handling sensitive information.
follow_up_questions: What role do SSL certificates play in HTTPS?
How does HTTPS impact website performance?

questions.text: Explain the concept of version control and why it's important in software development
questions.expected_answer: Version control is a system that tracks changes to files over time, allowing you to recall specific versions, compare changes, and collaborate with others. It's crucial in software development because it enables multiple developers to work on the same project simultaneously, provides a complete history of changes, allows rollback to previous versions when bugs are introduced, and facilitates branching and merging for feature development. Git is the most popular version control system today.
follow_up_questions: What's the difference between Git and GitHub?
Can you explain what a merge conflict is and how to resolve it?

questions.text: What is machine learning and how is it different from traditional programming?
questions.expected_answer: Machine learning is a subset of artificial intelligence where computers learn to make predictions or decisions by finding patterns in data, rather than being explicitly programmed for every scenario. In traditional programming, we write specific instructions to solve problems. In machine learning, we provide data and desired outcomes, and the algorithm learns the patterns to make predictions on new, unseen data. ML is particularly useful for complex problems like image recognition, natural language processing, and recommendation systems where writing explicit rules would be impractical.
follow_up_questions: What are the main types of machine learning?
Can you give an example of when you might choose machine learning over traditional programming?

questions.text: Explain what an API is and why APIs are important in modern software development
questions.expected_answer: An API (Application Programming Interface) is a set of protocols, routines, and tools that allows different software applications to communicate with each other. It defines how software components should interact, specifying the requests that can be made, how to make them, data formats, and conventions. APIs are crucial because they enable modularity, allow integration between different systems, promote code reusability, and enable the creation of ecosystems where different services can work together seamlessly.
follow_up_questions: What's the difference between REST and GraphQL APIs?
How do you ensure API security and authentication?

questions.text: What is cloud computing and what are its main service models?
questions.expected_answer: Cloud computing is the delivery of computing services (servers, storage, databases, networking, software) over the internet, allowing users to access resources on-demand without owning physical infrastructure. The main service models are: 1) IaaS (Infrastructure as a Service) - provides virtualized computing resources, 2) PaaS (Platform as a Service) - provides a platform for developing and deploying applications, and 3) SaaS (Software as a Service) - provides complete software applications over the internet. Benefits include scalability, cost-effectiveness, and reduced maintenance overhead.
follow_up_questions: What are the advantages and disadvantages of cloud computing?
Can you explain the difference between public, private, and hybrid clouds?

questions.title: Synchronous vs Asynchronous Code
questions.description: What is the difference between synchronous and asynchronous code in JavaScript?
questions.answer:
Synchronous code executes line by line in sequence, with each operation blocking until it completes before the next one begins. This can lead to performance issues when operations take a long time.

Asynchronous code allows operations to be initiated and then continue execution without waiting for the operation to complete. When the operation finishes, a callback function, promise, or async/await construct is used to handle the result. This non-blocking behavior is crucial for operations like network requests, file I/O, or timers in JavaScript, enabling responsive user interfaces and efficient resource utilization.

questions.title: JavaScript Threading Model & Behaviour
questions.description: Is JavaScript a single-threaded or multi-threaded language? How does it handle synchronous and asynchronous operations?
questions.answer:
Javascript is Single Threaded Synchronous language. To perform any time taking synchronous tasks, we have callback, Promises in Javascript, which we will cover in further questions.

  • JavaScript is a single-threaded language.
    It runs in a single-threaded environment, meaning it has one main call stack and can execute only one piece of code at a time. This is especially true in browsers, where JavaScript relies on a single thread for executing code.

  • Synchronous operations:
    Synchronous code in JavaScript is executed sequentially. Each operation must complete before the next one starts, and the thread is blocked until the current task finishes. Examples include basic statements, loops, and most function calls.

  • Asynchronous operations:
    Although JavaScript itself is single-threaded, it can handle asynchronous tasks using mechanisms like Web APIs (in browsers) or Node.js APIs (in server environments). Operations such as timers (setTimeout), network requests (fetch), and event listeners are processed outside the main thread. When these operations complete, their callbacks are placed in a task queue, and the event loop ensures they are executed when the call stack is empty.

  • The role of the event loop:
    The event loop coordinates the execution of synchronous code and the handling of asynchronous callbacks. This enables JavaScript to manage asynchronous tasks without blocking the main thread, providing a non-blocking, responsive programming model.

 

We will discuss the detailed execution of asynchronous JavaScript, including how the event loop, microtasks, and macrotasks work, in upcoming questions

questions.title: JavaScript Data Types
questions.description: What are the different data types in JavaScript?
questions.answer:
JavaScript has two main categories of data types:

**Primitive Data Types**:
1. **String**: Represents textual data (e.g., `'hello'`, `"world"`).
2. **Number**: Represents numeric values (e.g., `42`, `3.14`).
3. **Boolean**: Represents logical values (`true` or `false`).
4. **Undefined**: Represents a variable that has been declared but not assigned a value.
5. **Null**: Represents the intentional absence of any object value.
6. **Symbol** (ES6): Represents a unique and immutable primitive value.
7. **BigInt** (ES2020): Represents integers of arbitrary precision (e.g., `9007199254740991n`).

**Non-Primitive (Reference) Data Types**:
1. **Object**: A collection of key-value pairs (e.g., `{name: 'John', age: 30}`).
2. **Array**: An ordered collection of values (e.g., `[1, 2, 3]`).
3. **Function**: A callable object that executes a block of code.
4. **Date**: Represents dates and times.
5. **RegExp**: Represents regular expressions.
6. **Map**, **Set**, **WeakMap**, **WeakSet**: Collection objects introduced in ES6.

A key difference between primitive and reference types is how they're stored and compared:
- Primitive types are stored by value and compared by value.
- Reference types are stored by reference (memory address) and compared by reference.

questions.title: Type Coercion
questions.description: What is type coercion in JavaScript? Explain with an example.
questions.answer:
Process of converting one data type to another is known as Type Coercion.

There are two types of coercion:

  • Implicit coercion: Coercion occurs when JavaScript automatically converts values from one data type to another. This typically happens when a specific data type is expected in an operation or expression, but a different type is provided. In such cases, JavaScript internally attempts to convert the value to the expected type behind the scenes. 

    Example: `5 + '5'` results in the string `'55'` because the number 5 is coerced to a string when added to another string.
```javascript
   // Examples of implicit coercion
   5 + '5'        // "55" → number is coerced to string
   '10' == 10     // true → string is coerced to number
   if ('hello')   // true → non-empty string is coerced to boolean true
   






```
  •  Explicit coercion: When developers intentionally convert types using functions like `Number()`, `String()`, or `Boolean()`. Example: `Number('5')` explicitly converts the string '5' to the number 5. Another example of implicit coercion is in conditional statements: `if ('hello')` evaluates to true because non-empty strings are coerced to true in boolean contexts.

questions.title: String and Number based Type Coercion
questions.answer:
For '5' + 2, the result is '52'. For '5' - 2, the result is 3.

This difference occurs due to JavaScript's type coercion rules: 1.

  • The + operator has two functions: numeric addition and string concatenation. When one operand is a string, JavaScript prioritizes string concatenation, so the number 2 is coerced to a string '2' and concatenated with '5' to form '52'.
  • The - operator only performs numeric subtraction (there's no string 'subtraction' operation). Therefore, JavaScript coerces the string '5' to the number 5 before performing the subtraction, resulting in 3.

This behavior demonstrates JavaScript's context-sensitive type coercion, where the same value may be converted differently depending on the operation being performed.

questions.title: JavaScript Function Phases
questions.description: What happens in the creation and execution phase of a JavaScript function?
questions.answer:
When a JavaScript function is invoked, it goes through two main phases:

 

1. Creation Phase (also known as the Compilation Phase)

In this initial phase, the JavaScript engine scans the code before executing it, setting up memory for all variables and functions.

 

  • Variables declared withvar:

    • Memory is allocated.

    • They are initialized with the valueundefined.

  • Function declarations:

    • Memory is allocated.

    • The entire function definition is stored.

  • Variables declared withletandconst:

    • Memory is allocated.

    • They are not initialized yet.

    • These variables remain in a "Temporal Dead Zone" until execution reaches them.

 

2. Execution Phase

Once memory setup is complete, the engine begins executing the code line by line.

 

  • Code Execution:

    • The program runs from top to bottom.

  • Variable Initialization:

    • Variables declared withvar(which were initialized asundefinedin the creation phase) are now assigned their actual values.

  • Function Execution:

    • Functions, whose definitions were stored earlier, are now called and executed when reached.

    • A new Execution Context is created for each function invocation.

 

📝 Note:
Hoisting happens because of the Creation Phase.
It’s during this phase that variables and functions are moved (hoisted) to memory, which is why they can be accessed earlier in the code (with limitations).

questions.title: Execution Context
questions.description: What is the execution context in JavaScript?
questions.answer:
When Javascript engine scans a javascript file, it creates an environment that have access to all the variaables, functions required to execute a piece of code. This environment is known as execution context.

During Creation phase of javascript execution, a Global Execution context (GEC) is formed.
When a function is called, a seprate execution is created at the function level. This Function Execution Context (FEC) will have all the data required to execute that function.

Each execution context is maintained with a call stack, latest execution context being added to the top of stack. 

 

Explanation with Example:

 

In the following code snippet, When the program starts, the JavaScript engine creates the Global Execution Context and places it on the call stack.

```javascript
function first() {
  console.log("Inside first function");
  second();
  console.log("Exiting first function");
}

function second() {
  console.log("Inside second function");
}

console.log("Start");
first();
console.log("End");



```

When first() is called, a new Function Execution Context is created and pushed on top of the stack. Inside first(), another function second() is called, so another Execution Context is created and added to the top.

JavaScript always runs the top-most Execution Context first. Once second() finishes, its context is removed, and control returns to first(), and so on.

This Last In, First Out (LIFO) behavior is how the call stack works in JavaScript.

questions.title: Hoisting in JavaScript
questions.description: What is hoisting in JavaScript? What gets hoisted?
questions.answer:
Hoisting is JavaScript's behavior of moving declarations to the top of their containing scope during the compilation phase, before code execution. This means you can use variables and functions before they're actually declared in your code.

What gets hoisted:

1. **Function declarations** are fully hoisted with their definitions, so they can be called before they appear in the code.
   ```javascript
   sayHello(); // Works!
   function sayHello() { console.log('Hello'); }
   ```

2. **Variable declarations** using `var` are hoisted, but not their initializations. They're initialized with `undefined`.
   ```javascript
   console.log(x); // undefined (not ReferenceError)
   var x = 5;
   ```

3. **let and const declarations** are hoisted but not initialized, creating a "Temporal Dead Zone" where accessing them before declaration throws a ReferenceError.
   ```javascript
   console.log(y); // ReferenceError
   let y = 10;
   ```

4. **Class declarations** behave like `let`/`const` - they're hoisted but remain uninitialized until declaration.

5. **Function expressions** and **arrow functions** follow the hoisting rules of their declaration type (`var`, `let`, or `const`).

questions.title: JavaScript Scopes
questions.description: What is the difference between global, block, and lexical scope?

questions.title: Scope Chain
questions.description: How does the scope chain work in JavaScript?
questions.answer:
When a variable is used, JavaScript first checks if it exists in the current (local) scope. If it’s not there, it looks in the outer or parent scope. If it still can’t find it, it keeps going up through each parent scope.

This continues until the variable is found or until JavaScript reaches the global scope. This process of looking through the layers of scopes is called the scope chain.

 

  1. Every execution context has its own variable environment 
  2. Each function creates a new execution context when called
  3. Each context's lexical environment has a reference to its outer (parent) environment
  4. This chain of references forms the scope chain

 

For example:

 

```javascript
const global = 'global';
function outer() {
  const outerVar = 'outer';
  function inner() {
    const innerVar = 'inner';
    console.log(innerVar); // Looks in inner's scope
    console.log(outerVar); // Not found in inner, looks in outer's scope
    console.log(global);   // Not found in inner or outer, looks in global scope
  }
  inner();
}











```

 

This mechanism enables closures and is fundamental to how JavaScript manages variable access.

questions.title: Var, Let & Const variables
questions.description: What are the differences between var, let, and const?
questions.answer:
Scope

  • var is function-scoped, not block-scoped.

    ✅ Note: People often think var is global-scoped — it's not. It's scoped to the entire function in which it's declared. It means that a variable declared with var is accessible anywhere within the function in which it's declared — but not outside of it, even if declared inside a block like an if or for.

    ```javascript
var a = 5;
function example() {
  if (true) {
    var b = 10;
  }
  console.log(b); // ✅ 10 — accessible because it's scoped to the whole function
}

example();
console.log(a); // ✅ 5 — if variable is initialized in global context, it is attached to global object which is expected behaviour
console.log(b); // ❌ ReferenceError — b is not defined outside the function










```

  •  let and const are block-scoped — limited to { } like inside if, for, or while blocks.

    ```javascript
function example() {
  if (true) {
    let b = 20;
    const c = 30;
  }
  console.log(b); // ❌ ReferenceError
  console.log(c); // ❌ ReferenceError
}

example();



```

Hoisting

  • All three (var, let, and const) are hoisted to the top of their scope.

    ✅ Note: A common myth is that let and const are not hoisted — they are, but they remain uninitialized in a Temporal Dead Zone (TDZ) until the line where they’re declared.

  • var is hoisted and initialized as undefined.

Re-declaration

  • var can be re-declared in the same scope.

  • let and const cannot be re-declared in the same block scope.

Re-assignment

  • var and let can be reassigned to new values.

  • const cannot be reassigned — it must remain constant after initialization.

Initialization

  • var and let can be declared without a value.

  • const must be initialized during declaration.

Global Object

  • var, when declared in the global scope, becomes a property of the global object (window in browsers).

    ✅ window.varName will work.

  • let and const do not attach to the global object.

questions.title: Temporal Dead Zone
questions.description: What is the Temporal Dead Zone (TDZ) in JavaScript?
questions.answer:
The Temporal Dead Zone (TDZ) is a behavior in JavaScript that occurs with variables declared using let and const

 

When JavaScript let and const variables, memory is allocated for them, but they are not initialized immediately.

 

They exist in the scope but remain in an "uninitialized" state until the code reaches their declaration.

 

If you try to access such a variable before it’s initialized, JavaScript throws a ReferenceError, saying the variable can't be accessed before initialization.

 

So, the TDZ refers to the time between when the variable’s scope is entered (due to hoisting) and the point where it is actually declared and initialized in the code.

 

For example:

```javascript
{
  // TDZ starts for x
  console.log(x); // ReferenceError: Cannot access 'x' before initialization
  let x = 10; // TDZ ends for x
}

























```

 

The TDZ exists to catch programming errors and enforce better variable declaration practices. It differs from `var` variables, which are initialized with `undefined` during hoisting and can be accessed (though they'll have the value `undefined`) before their declaration in the code. The TDZ also applies to class declarations and the parameters of default functions when the default value references the parameter itself or parameters defined later in the same parameter list.

questions.title: Higher-Order Functions
questions.description: What is a higher-order function? Give an example.
questions.answer:
A higher-order function is a function that either:

1. Takes one or more functions as arguments, and/or

2. Returns a function as its result

 

This concept is fundamental to functional programming in JavaScript and enables powerful patterns like function composition, currying, and abstractions over behavior.

 

Examples:

```javascript
// EXAMPLE 1:
// function like map, filter, reduce accepts another function
const numbers = [1, 2, 3, 4, 5];
const doubled = numbers.map(num => num * 2); // map takes a function as an argument

// EXAMPLE 2:
// function multiplier is returning a function (classic example of closure as well)
function multiplier(factor) {
  // Returns a new function
  return function(number) {
    return number * factor;
  };
}

const double = multiplier(2); // double is a function returned by multiplier
console.log(double(5))        // 10


// EXAMPLE 3:
// FUNCTION COMPOSITION
function compose(f, g) {
  return function(x) {
    return f(g(x));
  };
}

const addOne = x => x + 1;
const square = x => x * x;
const addOneThenSquare = compose(square, addOne);

console.log(addOneThenSquare(3)); // 16 (square(addOne(3)) = square(4) = 16)










```

Higher-order functions allow for more modular, reusable, and declarative code.

questions.title: First-Class Functions
questions.description: What does it mean that JavaScript has first-class functions?
questions.answer:
In JavaScript, functions are also referred to as first-class citizens, which means they are treated like any other variable.

 

This fundamental characteristic enables many of JavaScript's powerful capabilities and functional programming patterns.

 

Being first-class functions means functions can be assigned to variables, can be passed as arguments to other functions, can be returned from other functions, can be stored in data structures, can have properties and methods

 

```javascript
   const greet = function(name) { return `Hello, ${name}!`; }; //Functions can be assigned to variables

// function being passed as arguments to other functions
[1, 2, 3].map(function(num) { return num * 2; });

// being returned from other functions
function createMultiplier(factor) {
     return function(number) { return number * factor; };
   }

// can be stores in object keys
const operations = {
     add: (a, b) => a + b,
     subtract: (a, b) => a - b
   };

// can have properties and methods
function counter() { counter.count++; }
   counter.count = 0;








```

This feature enables higher-order functions, callbacks, closures, and many other advanced patterns that make JavaScript flexible and expressive.
